abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Private Sector
            Development Support Project for Afghanistan were as follows:
            outcomes were unsatisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was high, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            recent reviews and studies on international experience
            relating to industrial parks (and special economic zones)
            also suggest that a more efficient approach to the
            development of IPs is to rely on public private
            partnerships, where the private sector is responsible for
            the construction and management of parks. 'Flexibility
            in design' can seem an evasive concept in an
            infrastructure project. However, the deterioration of
            security (or the lack of long term visibility and possible
            change of environment) should probably always, at least, be
            considered a risk in a conflict context. In this respect,
            options to quickly reorient the use of Project funds might
            have been identified at preparation, for example, to support
            other IPs already under construction with the support of
            other donors. The decision to use Afghanistan Investment
            Support Authority (AISA), supported by individual
            consultants, to undertake the construction of the industrial
            park appears, in retrospect, to have been ill-informed.
            Building an industrial park requires a variety of highly
            specialized expertise that only an engineering firm can
            mobilize. While the focus on building AISA's capacity
            was well founded, the approach to build its capacity through
            individual consultants was not appropriate, when it came to
            building a large industrial park.
